My own definition of "personhood" is a bit different than yours since I do not require communication. After all, there is little or nothing that we can communicate in sleep or in coma, and early babies have very limited communication - does that make us any less a person in those circumstances? My definition of "person" only has two requirements:
 1) The being is human - i.e. human DNA
 2) The being has at least the beginnings of a mental existence (either conscious or subconscious).
 
 I require a mental existence since I do not believe a living body without a mind can be considered a person. Outside of the abortion debate, all of our uses of the term "person" imply a mental existence. Also, I require the being to be human since many animals also have a mental existence. However, though I advocate against animal cruelty, I would not give animals the same rights as we people have. One can envision future scenarios of human-animal hybrids or even aliens where such a definition might be challenged, but we haven't faced those scenarios yet.
 
 As for when we first become "people" and when we lose that distinction, I would point out that neurologists associate higher brain functions with our abilities to think, have emotions, register pain, etc. The function of the higher brain (cerebral cortex) can be monitored by measuring certain types of EEG patterns. Apparently, such higher level EEG patterns can first be detected around the 30th week (near the beginning of the third trimester of pregnancy) so I would say that that is the point at which we first have the possibility of acquiring a mind - and thus, that is when we might first start to exist as "people". Once those EEG patterns end at the end of our lives, indicating that the higher brain is no longer functional, then we no longer have a mental existence and, in my view, we are then no longer "people". One can continue to keep our bodies alive artificially but, as people, we are long gone.

To begin with, we must remember that the category of personhood is our creation, and our definitions of what constitutes personhood are therefore completely arbitrary. It is not a workable ethical category for anybody. For the theist, this understanding of personhood steps on the toes of the much less capricious body of revelation on the topic of what makes humans valuable or worth considering whole. For the non-theist, the separation of humans (or some humans) into persons that are above the rest of the world in some mode of value is one more chunk of humanistic chauvinism, a completely unjustifiable and capricious move.
 
 Therefore, the question of when a human becomes a person or ceases to be a person is hardly a discussion (given the definition). The beginning and end of personhood will correspond to the arbitrary qualities by which you choose to define personhood. In the case of your definition, it begins after birth and lasts until braindeath. I understand "think" in your use to be equivalent with self-consciousness. If it is "think" in some broader sense then we will have many persons outside of the human race.  I'm not completely sure what you mean by "personal identity", but it sounds similar to what I called "sense of self". It is a hard term to define. 
 
 Sense of self is different than a recognition of self. I have heard that babies do not have a recognition of self - in the sense that, though they have personal experiences of pain, sensation, etc, they do not recognize themselves as separate from others - they just don't think about their separateness so there is no recognition of a separate "I". Similarly, most animals may have a sense of self - they may have a central mental center which feels the sensations, experiences the emotions, etc. - but many do not necessarily have a recognition of themselves as an "I" and others as "you". They just don't think about the separateness - they just have experiences that they react to. 
 
 Where mental existence is concerned and criteria I use to define it, many of the criteria I listed (thought, emotion, sense of pain, perception of experiences, sense of self, etc.) are interdependent (ex. emotion can be thought of as a type of thought, it takes a type of thought to recognize pain or sensation, etc.). However, roughly speaking, I would say that "any of the above" criteria would be enough to define a minimum mental existence - and thus define a person.
 
 On a last point, why is memory important to you? Various people who have experienced major brain trauma have lost most memory function - so they have no memory of who they are, what they were doing one minute ago, etc. One can imagine that the extreme situation would be someone who has no memory at all - so he has no words to communicate, no memory of a personal history. Indeed, every experience is completely new, including the experience of pain, pleasure, etc. However, this memory-less person can still have experiences (feel pain, pleasure, experience the input of the senses, etc.). He would be completely baffled as to what any experience at all is telling him, but he would still have the experiences. Extremely limited as that person would be, I would still call him a person. I'm not sure if that is the type of memory that you were referring to. If not, then please clarify.

 I would differentiate between biologically registering a sensation and mentally registering one. Our bodies allow for a wide range of reflex reactions that are signs that our bodies have registered a sensation. There are apparently short cuts in the nervous system that allow for such reflex reactions to happen at a fast rate by circumventing the processing of the cerebral cortex. This fast response has proven useful from an Evolutionary standpoint since a slower reaction often could lead to death.
 
 However, to mentally register a sensation (such as pain), one needs the cerebral cortex to do some processing - at least as determined by various academic and medical professionals who have looked into the issue of fetal pain. Here is one link to a comprehensive study on fetal pain made by the American Medical Association:
 http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/short/294/8/947 
 
 One of my main points in the previous posts was that registering of sensations (in a mental sense, not purely a biological sense) is a sign of a rudimentary mind and, therefore, in my view, a person. Since such mental processing requires a cerebral cortex, which is not sufficiently developed until roughly the beginning of the third trimester, then I agree with you on the timing of when a fetus can be called a person. In this post, I am simply making clear that by "registering of sensations", I meant mentally registering that sensation - not just physically/biologically.

 I have seen many nature documentaries where individuals might occasionally change groups - be it a stray male kicked out of neighboring group that takes over an existing independent group, or a stray individual that gets adopted by a group, but these events do not happen too often. Also, groups of animals - such as apes - do interact with other groups in what is essentially warfare over territory. However, I admit that I have not heard of two independent groups of apes interacting peacefully. Indeed, though I have seen nature documentaries showing many fights between groups of animals, I don't think that I have ever seen cooperation between separate groups - interesting to ponder. I have heard of certain tool use among apes quickly spreading from the ape that "invented" a particular tool use to the whole group, but I haven't heard of such acquired "culture" spreading through an ape population of a wider region. This lack of cooperation with other groups might well be one of the numerous aspects limiting the mental development of higher mammals.

I have dealt with enough of such people in my life to know how very frustrating it can be to deal with. I think that part of their mentality is that they do not trust their own capabilities of reason and find strength in an absolute trust in their narrowly defined group - in that their group leader tells them what to think and they trust that. They essentially do not allow themselves the freedom to judge for themselves. It is a pity since this allows so many people to be lead astray by charismatic leaders. This is even true at a national level - more so with Republicans I have met than with Democrats (though I admit to being biased). So many of the world problems would be more easily solved if people consistently demanded solid reasoning from their leaders and did not trust blindly.
